On the other side, the ratio of positive surprises to disappointments is running at very high levels in Health Care (5.1), and Industrials (6.1) and Staples (4.0). Energy, with a surprise ratio of 3.0, has the highest median surprise.

In terms of year-over-year growth, Energy is the clear winner, with half the Energy firms reporting year-over-year EPS growth in excess of 29.3%. Since all the energy firms have their numbers in, that number will not change. Tech holds the silver with 18.5% growth, while Industrials hold the bronze at 16.9%. Honorable (double digit) mentions go to Health Care, Telecom and Staples. Financials and Discretionary are both posting negative growth, while Materials and Utilities were barely positive.

Keep in mind what the median measures. It is a gauge of what the "normal" firm will report in terms of EPS. It is not influenced significantly by extreme data points, and implicitly treats the results from Exxon Mobil (XOM  -  Free Report), General Electric (GE  -  Free Report) and Wal-Mart (WMT  -  Free Report) the as being just as important as the results for Murphy Oil (MUR  -  Free Report), Manitowoc (MTW  -  Free Report) and Big Lots (BIG  -  Free Report). Changes in shares outstanding, due to buybacks or new issuance also affect the results in this measure, while they do not affect total net income.

Turning now to the "worst of times" in this tale of two markets. Total net income reported is 17.9% below the total net income that those same 444 firms reported in the first quarter of 2007. (This is an improvement from the -23.2% they reported in the fourth quarter.)  Specifically, reported firms earned $157.8 billion on a net basis (before non-recurring items) this year and $191.9 billion last year.

The Financials have been responsible for more than all of the drop in net income though. Total earnings in the sector are off 79.6% to $12.1 billion versus the $53.4 billion they reported a year ago. That is a drop of $47.3 billion versus a drop of just $34.1 billion for the market as a whole. Put another way, if the Financials are excluded, then total net income is actually up 9.9%. The actual picture is some what wore than that for the Financials since some of there problems have been taken in the form of one time extraordinary charges, or have not even shown up on the income statement (just hits to the balance sheet taken in other comprehensive income).

Lets put what is happening to the Financials another way. At this point in the earnings season the Financials had earned more than the next two highest sectors (Energy and Health Care) with the Materials sector thrown in for good measure. This year they are in sixth place, behind Energy, Health Care, Industrials, Tech and Staples. On the other hand, in the fourth quarter they were dead last as the sector as a whole was bleeding red ink.

The biggest earnings gains so far have been in the Energy sector, with total net income 25.6% above last year, and in the Material sector, with a gain of 14.3%. Both have all the reports in so those numbers are now fixed. Consumer Staples (+13.7%) and Tech (+12.6%) are both also having very solid quarters on a total net income basis. While the Financials are clearly the core of the problem in terms of weak earnings, it has not been a good quarter so far for the Durables (down 23.5%). Health Care is up just 4.9%, a very significant slowdown from the 18.2% growth it showed in the fourth quarter. The poor showing in Industrials (up just 4.4%) is in large part due to GE.

If all the remaining firms come in and match expectations the decline in total earnings should be down 18.5%, a slight deterioration over what the numbers are showing right now. That would be an improvement over the decline that we saw in the fourth quarter (22.8%).

To help gauge the direction of the market, we take note of what analysts are thinking. By tallying their EPS changes, we can determine our revisions ratio. This ratio simply divides the total number of positive estimate revisions by the total number of estimate cuts. Thus, a high ratio is a bullish indicator and a low ratio is bearish. For the S&P 500 as a whole, a number below 0.80 or above 1.25 is generally significant. For individual sectors the distance from 1.0 should be greater for the numbers to be significant.

The revisions ratio is trending up and this week made it just barely into positive territory (>1.0). While the reading of 1.02 should be interpreted more as neutral than positive, it is nice to see it climb over the dividing line. With positive surprises running more than 2:1 over disappointments, one should expect to see more increases than cuts in full year expectations. After all, first quarter earnings are part of full year earnings, thus if a firm reports higher than expected earnings for the quarter, and the analyst does not raise his full year numbers by the amount of the beat, he is implicitly cutting his estimates for the rest of the year.

We did see, however, a nice improvement, with the ratio rising to 1.02 from 0.90 last week and 0.67 two weeks ago. It does appear that the analysts are reacting to the better than expected results posted so far. The overall pace of estimate revisions is approaching what should be the peak for this quarter. Over the last four weeks there have been 3,543 changes in estimates: 1,790 up and 1,753 down. Either this week or next should mark the peak of total revisions activity for the quarter.

The ratio of firms with rising mean estimates to falling mean estimates is 0.96, in line with the revisions ratio, and in neutral territory. Five sectors, Industrials, Energy, Consumer Staples, Materials and Health Care are solidly in positive territory. The Financials and The Consumer Discretionary sectors continue to be the weakest, as they have for many months now. However, even there, the ratios have more than doubled off their lows.

The Energy sector topped the chart this week with a revisions ratio of 2.30. The general story is: Upstream good, downstream bad. The Exploration and Production firms such as Anadarko (APC), XTO Energy (XTO) and EOG Resources (EOG  -  Free Report) were noteworthy for their strength. The independent refiners like Tesoro (TSO) and Valero (VLO  -  Free Report) bucked the trend and were weak. As angry as people are about prices at the pump, this is strong evidence that it is the price of crude, not huge downstream (refining and marketing) profits that are the heart of the problem.
The Industrials had the next best revisions ratio this week at 1.91. The strength was mostly due to the Rails, Aerospace and Heavy Machinery firms.

The Financial sector continues to get slammed with estimate cuts, currently running at three times as many as estimate increases. Banks, Brokers and Insurance companies were all slammed with cuts, and there seemed few places to hide. However, the sector is not alone. The Discretionary sector also had more than two times as many cuts as increases. Retailers were noteworthy in their weakness, with Kohls (KSS  -  Free Report), Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) and Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) some of the poorest performers.

The 2009 revisions story is similar to the 2008 story. The revisions ratio is well below one but improving at 0.88, up from 0.81 last week, and 0.64 two weeks ago. Analysts seem to be suspecting that the period of earnings weakness stemming from the soft economy could last quite a while. The most strength comes from the commodity sensitive Energy and Materials sectors. The Industrials also joined the party this week, mostly due to strength at the same sorts of firms that were strong for 2008. Energy lead the parade this week with almost three increases for every cut. The strong firms were very similar to those for 2008, but the downstream firms were not as weak. The strength in the sector was very widespread.

The revisions picture for the Financial sector is even worse for 2009 than it is for 2008, coming in at 0.24, or more than four cuts for every increase. Revisions like these will eat away at the robust earnings rebound seen for 2009 (unless 2008 gets cut faster). We do not seem to be getting out of the woods on the Financial sector front. While the weakness was widespread, Banks like Comerica (CMA  -  Free Report), National City (NCC), Wachovia (WB) Wells Fargo (WFC  -  Free Report) and Zion (ZION  -  Free Report) were particularly hard hit.

The total number of revisions for the whole S&P 500 for 2009 is also nearing its seasonal peak. There were a total of 2,782 revisions: 1,300 up and 1,482 down. This is up 13.6% from 2,449 (1,095 up and 1,354 down) last week. As with the 2008 revisions, this number is within a few weeks of its peak for the quarter. The ratio of firms with rising mean estimates to falling mean estimates is 0.81, somewhat weaker than the revisions ratio, and still very much in negative territory.

When making investment decisions, growth should always be looked at in conjunction with how much you are paying for a stock. Thus, it makes sense to look at the total earnings expected for a sector, relative to that sectors total market capitalization. This is basically a variation on looking at the P/E.

The chart below shows the share of total earnings for 2007, 2008 and 2009, as well as the share of total market capitalization for each sector (the final bar shown). Since the S&P 500 is a market cap weighted index, this is the same as its index weight. On the chart below, the difference between the sizes of the first three bars shows if a sector is gaining or losing "earnings share". The difference between the final bar and the first three bars shows if the sector is selling for an above or below market P/E. If the final bar is smaller than the other bars, the sector is selling for a below market P/E. However, as opposed to just showing the sector P/Es, it also shows the relative importance of the sectors to the overall index.

For years, the Financials were the dominate force in the market, both in terms of market cap, and even more so in terms of total earnings. They have now been dethroned on both counts. Still, despite their current problems, the Financials are still a very significant influence on the market. However, it is now likely that they will lose the earnings crown this year to the Energy sector. Even with all the disasters in the sector, for 2007, the Financials accounted for 22.2% of the total net income for the S&P 500. In 2008, that is currently expected to decline to 17.3% before rebounding to 20.8% in 2009. However, in recent years the sector has accounted for well over a quarter of all earnings. While Energy has usurped the crown this year, analysts expect a restoration next year, with the sectors share rebounding to 20.8% while Energy slips back to 16.3%. On the market cap (and index weight) front, Tech overtook the Financials this week 16.7% to 16.4%. Given the ongoing estimate cuts in the sector, and the estimate increases in the Energy sector, I suspect the Energy sector might just keep its crown in 2009 as well, but that is a long shot prediction.

For many years Financials were clearly the dominate factor in the overall market, despite generally selling for below market P/Es. Based on 2008 earnings, the Financials have a P/E of 14.4x and based on 2009, only 10.2x. However given the pace of estimate cuts in the sector, the true P/E is probably higher since the actual earnings will be significantly lower. Energy has just taken the throne as the cheapest based on 2008 earnings, trading at 11.6x, and 11.0x based on 2009 expectations. Keep your eyes on the revisions. Unless the spreading of economic weakness to the rest of the world causes oil prices to plunge (and the recent trends are very much in the other direction), you can have much more confidence in Energy earnings forecasts actually being achieved (or exceeded) than is true with the Financials.

While Energy accounts for only 13.85% of the total market cap of the S&P 500, it was responsible for 15.8% of 2007 earnings and is expected to be the source of 18.1% of 2008 earnings (falling to 16.3% in 2009). Tech is the most expensive sector of the market on a P/E basis. It has a 16.67% weight in the index but was responsible for only 11.7% of 2007 earnings. However, Techs earnings share is expected to rise to13.1% in 2008 and 13.0% in 2009.

The S&P 500 as a whole is trading for 15.2x and 12.9x, 2008 and 2009 earnings, respectively. Based on a blend of 67% 2008 earnings and 33% 2009 earnings; that translates to a 6.93% earnings yield, which looks extremely cheap relative to a 3.77% ten year T-note. Even against the AA corporate bond yield of 5.83% it looks attractive. However, the current level of expectations for corporate earnings still implies that profits will stay well above their historical averages as a share of GDP. That would be an exceedingly rare occurrence during a recession. The comparison between the earnings yield on the S&P and the 10-year T-note is in my opinion more a reflection of the extreme unattractiveness of long term T-notes at this point than stocks looking particularly cheap in general, however there are attractive stocks out there. It appears that the flight to quality has caused a massive bubble in the price of T-notes. The prices are hard to justify given the risk that the massive injections of liquidity by the Fed to ameliorate the credit crunch will end up fueling the fires of inflation.
Neil Malkin contributed significantly to this report.
Data in this report, unless stated otherwise, is through the close on Thursday 5/8/2008
